title: 106_hr4521
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the Going-to-the-Sun Road is historically significant and has suffered structural damage since opening in 1932. Infrastructure at developed areas is inadequate for cold-season operation, and maintenance backlogs exist. The historic hotels in Glacier National Park, including Many Glacier Hotel and Lake McDonald Lodge, are essential for public use but are significantly deteriorated and in need of substantial repair to meet basic needs and expectations. The hotels in Glacier National Park need significant repairs due to deferred maintenance, potentially exceeding investor financing capacity. The current season of operation is limited to 4 months due to lacking infrastructure and heating systems. The National Park Service may require additional authority for demonstration projects under the Concessions Management Improvement Act of 1998. A demonstration project is needed for the repair of historic hotels in Glacier National Park. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as Advisory Committee, Park, and Secretary. SEC. 3. GOING-TO-THE-SUN ROAD STUDY. The Secretary, in consultation with the Advisory Committee, must complete a feasibility study for rehabilitating Going-to-the-Sun Road by December 31, 2001. The study includes alternatives, time estimates, mitigation efforts, costs, benefits, economic impacts, and long-term maintenance needs. The Secretary, in consultation with the Advisory Committee, must complete a feasibility study for rehabilitating Going-to-the-Sun Road by December 31, 2001. The study includes alternatives, time estimates, mitigation efforts, costs, benefits, economic impacts, long-term maintenance needs, environmental impact statement draft, and transportation system improvements analysis. Nothing in this section affects the duty of the Secretary to continue the program for preserving, maintaining, and addressing safety concerns related to Going-to-the-Sun Road. After completing the study, the Secretary shall implement the plan promptly. The Secretary, after completing the feasibility study for rehabilitating Going-to-the-Sun Road, must consider Advisory Committee recommendations, choose a rehabilitation alternative based on the final environmental impact statement, and begin implementation of the chosen plan. Authorized actions include road rehabilitation, transportation system improvements, and seeking funding for long-term maintenance needs identified in the study. A report must be submitted within 30 days of study completion. The Secretary must submit a report to specified committees within 30 days of completing the feasibility study for rehabilitating Going-to-the-Sun Road. An authorization of $200,000,000 is provided for the Secretary to carry out the study, including implementing the plan and covering necessary environmental or cultural documentation and monitoring costs. SEC. 4. MAINTENANCE AND UPGRADE OF UTILITY SYSTEMS. The Secretary will upgrade and maintain utility systems for the Park and related facilities. $20,000,000 is authorized for this purpose. SEC. 5. VISITOR FACILITIES PLAN. The Secretary must complete a comprehensive plan for visitor facilities in the Park by December 31, 2001. This plan includes a commercial services plan and a plan for private financing of rehabilitation of historic lodging facilities. Options for financing may include historic tax credits and extending the visitor season. The Secretary must complete a comprehensive plan for visitor facilities in the Park by December 31, 2001, including a financial analysis, assistance for tour bus restoration, a new visitors center plan, and a parkwide resources assessment. The Secretary is required to complete a comprehensive plan for visitor facilities in the Park, including a financial analysis, assistance for tour bus restoration, a new visitors center plan, and a parkwide resources assessment. The plan must be submitted to the relevant committees in Congress, implemented promptly, and includes a request for $1,000,000 in appropriations. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 17, 2000.
